												I want to like this game. I want to like it so much, but I can't. For every right thing this game does there are three things done wrong.Most glaringly, the game performs terribly on its higher settings. I have a GTX 770 with a 570 for PhysX, 16 GB RAM, and an i5 overclocked to 4 Ghz. It can't handle AgrarSim 2013 on anything higher than Medium. Know this before playing it.Now on to the gameplay. Common to all the other farming simulations out there, the game's tutorial only cares about teaching you how to operate the machinery. The tutorial doesn't tell you anything about:1. Making fields (you can just plow anywhere, it turns out, and marking them out on the map is only for the benefit of AI workers).2. How and where to sell your harvest (the mill, the town, the agrarian centre).3. How and where to buy the things you need, like animals, seeds, and fertilisers (seed bags from town, seed loads from the agrarian centre, animals from the stables).4. How to buy new equipment (the O key).5. The differences between scenarios (the two hardest scenarios for each map have the same descriptions, but the second one is easier because it gives you an extra $10,000 and some basic machinery).6. Where things are on the map and how to use the map view.7. How to advance to the next day (hold down Ctrl and click on the sun icon near the clock).The game requires a LOT of micro-management. You need to drive your harvest to the sale point. You need to buy individual bags of seed to load the bottom-of-the-line ('historical') seeder, and you need to load those bags into the seeder yourself. There is a grain shower that you can use to load trailers with grain from your silo, but you can't use it to load the historical seeder. You need a gravity hopper to bag your grain so that you can load the seeder. You need to drive your machinery all the way to the agrarian centre to sell it, and in the early game your tractor does an average of 15 mph, so it takes about 10 minutes to travel anywhere.AgrarSim 2013 is also legendary for its crazy physics and unintuitive behaviour. Attachments fall at awkward angles that prevent attachment, and there's no way to rescue or reset them. A several-ton combine harvester can do a backflip when driven over a furrow at 5 mph. The historical seeder can often go nuts and flip your tractor over. There's no way to nudge around an unhitched trailer on foot, so you need to keep adjusting your tractor. If you try to sprint while carrying a seed bag, its collider bumps up against you and slows you down. The on-foot FOV is the narrowest I've ever seen in a video game (45° horizontal), and you will be disoriented for a second or two every time you step off the tractor. The mill won't buy trailers full of grain from you, it only wants bags. A MILL, FOR GOD'S SAKE. And one time I loaded some bags of grain onto a trailer and brought it halfway home, then saved the game and played something else. When I reloaded, the grain bags were gone! Just disappeared into the aether, never to be seen again!And yet for all its massive, unforgiveable problems and its numerous hair-tearing moments of frustration and confusion, AgrarSim offers something you can't get out of any other game right now. Because you see, when you drop a plow into the ground in AgrarSim, it actually digs out a furrow. It's a hole, an excavation, you can stand inside it. And when you drag a cultivator over that land, it smooths the furrows out. The simple act of working the soil is immediate and rewarding, and when you seed it and see your crops springing up there's a great sense of satisfaction and wonder.I think as a gaming experience, this game is worth about $5. As a simulator it's worth about $0.50. The gameplay is just too unpredictable. But it sure is fun to work the land!

												Agricultural Simulator 2013 - Steam Edition, is a simulator that allows you to learn all of the aspects of running a modern farm, from the comfort of your chair. As far as simulators go, it is one of the easiest I've seen in a long time. The tutorial walks you through each step and let's you play through the process of how to hook up and unhook equipment, manage fields and livestock, maintaining your equipment, as well as much more. You are given a choice of 4 different regions to choose from, as well as three different maps. The farm equipment used in-game, is based on actual equipment farmers use,  bringing another immersive level to the game. Campaign mode is available, aside from tutorial missions, and you can also start a new game and build your own fully functioning Agricultural Farm from the ground up with only the bare minimum. Campaign mode has several missions for you to complete, for those want a little more direction, and there are a bunch of different types of crops you can grow. They seem to have a pretty healthy selection, each with their own challenges and rewards. All in all this is a pretty fun simulator, which kind of surprised me. I didn't think farming would actually be fun, but if you like simulator games, this is a good one to try out.

												I just wanted to write this down in case I die in my sleep tonite. Heed my warning: Agricultural Simulation 2013 is beyond my mortal comprehension. I have now seen the true face of evil.The best part of this game was the menu screen, and just because it was in HD. And it had a tractor in it. I was sceptic at best, but proceeded to selection screen. "Hmm, Tuscany, that seems nice enough", I thought to myself. Without any ceremonies, the game dumps me onto a courtyard filled with chickens, multiple buildings, a dog and a tractor. In glorious 3D, except ran through multiple gaussian blur filters.Chickens flee at my wake as I run around the yard for a while. I take my hands off the keyboard, and my farmer alter ego keeps running. I disconnect gamepad and joystick, to no avail. Dog on the yard barks as I strafe around the yard, unable to stop. I try to steer myself towards the tractor standing in the corner of the yard, but I just climb over the damn thing and keep on running. Finally, after fiddling around with sound (wtf?!) options, I manage to disable the mystical autopilot feature.I fiddle around with tractor for a while, managing to fire it up. The farmer is walking faster than the damn machine, so I just ditch it. I start rummaging through the multitude of various buildings around. I find some supplies from the cellar of my house. Items vanish into thin air as the farmer uses his nifty jedi powers to move sacks, milk containers and crates of fruit around.I spot some livestock on the other side of the yard. Apparently I have some cows, a horse and a sheep or two. They make funny sounds when you click them. After few clicks I realize I have now managed to lock my horse into infite rotating loop. Few short moments later all my livestock are rotating around like some ♥♥♥♥ed up experimental farm yard merry-go-round. The display is too grotesque to behold, so I close the pen behind me, jump onto my trusty Massey-Ferguson and ride out of the farm.Massey charges forward like a crippled manatee. I manage to enable autopilot again, and the top speed settles around 10. Mph or Kph, I have no clue. Running would be faster, but I dare not to challenge the wilds by foot. I take a smoke break. Get some late night snack. Take a leak. I come back to find massey around 100m away from the farm. In my frustration, I steer right, and all the rules of physics and universe fly out of the window. Massey's nose goes up, right around it's axle, and I land the vehicle upside down. My farmer doesn't give a flying ♥♥♥♥ as the camera clips inside his skull, apparently the weight of the tractor doesn't really bother him.At this point, I pressed escape, exited the game, uninstalled it and removed it from my Steam game list.
